In Java, the List interface is part of the java.util package, and it extends the collection
interface, which means that it inherits many useful methods for working with groups of
objects.
Now, Lists maintain the order of elements as they are inserted, and this makes this List
interface very useful when order is important, right?
So for instance, when you have a to-do list, or when you have a queue system, or when you
have a playlist.
Say you want to play a playlist of songs and you want to be playing each song, a list might
be the right tool for you.
Another key feature of List, the interface, is that it allows duplicate elements.
This means that you can add the same item multiple times, and there's no restrictions for that.
This makes it different from sets.
If you remember for 5001, when we talk about sets, sets do not allow duplicates.
The List interface has multiple implementations.
We have already talked about the two main implementations, which are ArrayList and LinkList.
And just as a reminder, in case you have missed the previous videos, ArrayList is backed by an
array, and it provides fast random access.
So ArrayList, it's the right implementation if you're dealing with situations where you need
to read data frequently.
Now, LinkList uses a doubly linked list under the hood, which makes it more efficient for
inserting and deleting items, elements, in the middle of the list or the beginning of the
list.
